justification: The authors state that they "fit [the model] to data from the sustained attention to response task (SART …) whose repetitive nature produces a mixture of more strongly evidence-based decisions and rhythmic, time-based responses," indicating the task is used to capture lapses of sustained attention / mind-wandering.

In validating the timing component, the paper notes that "the timing component did the same for interval production" in a paradigm "where the same participants estimated temporal intervals," showing interval-production trials are the instrument for assessing timing precision.

When analysing the speed-accuracy trade-off, the authors "tested 19 participants on a perceptual random-dot-motion task" with fast, neutral, or accurate deadlines, demonstrating that this task operationalises decision making under time pressure.

For the second data set, "Wagenmakers et al. (2008) tested participants in a lexical decision task" while manipulating speed versus accuracy emphasis, using the task to measure how word-recognition decisions reflect the speed-accuracy trade-off.
